Editor’s choice paper The effect of syngas composition on the Fischer Tropsch synthesis over three-dimensionally ordered macro-porous iron based catalyst Jun Han a Li Zhang a Yongwu Lu b Jin Hu b Baobao Cao c Fei Yu b ⁎ a College of Resources and Environment Engineering, Wuhan University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, Hubei 430081, China College of Resources and Environment Engineering Wuhan University of Science and Technology Wuhan Hubei 430081 China b Department of Agricultural and Biological Engineering, Mississippi State University, MS 39762, USA Department of Agricultural and Biological Engineering Mississippi State University, MS 39762 USA c Key Lab of Advanced Technology of Materials, Southwest Jiaotong University, Chengdu, Sichuan 610031, China Key Lab of Advanced Technology of Materials Southwest Jiaotong University Chengdu Sichuan 610031 China ⁎ Corresponding author at: Department of Agricultural and Biological Engineering, Mississippi State University, 130 Creelman Street, MS, 39762, USA. Graphical abstract Three-Dimensionally Ordered Macro-porous (3DOM) Fe based catalysts were synthesized via a facile “glyoxylate route” poly (methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) colloidal crystal template (CCT) method. Fischer Tropsch Synthesis (FT) using different biosyngasses over the 3DOM Fe based catalyst for producing the liquid hydrocarbon was studied. The morphology, structure and microstructures of 3DOM Fe based catalysts were characterized by SEM, BET, TPR, HRTEM, XRD, XPS and DRIFTS. The experimental results demonstrated that the hydrogen lean syngas decreased the partial pressure of H2/CO, which caused the decrease of the CO conversion rate during FT reaction. Moreover, the addition of CO2 and CH4 in the hydrogen lean syngas could well preserve the iron carbide phase in the catalyst, and the CO conversion rate was improved. Lower H2/CO ratio syngas would shift the liquid hydrocarbon distribution to higher molecular weight hydrocarbons, and the addition of CO2 and CH4 into the syngas further facilitated the shift. Meanwhile, it was also found that the CO conversion rate and C5+ selectivity were 68.23% and 70.44% respectively during the simulated biosyngas from biomass gasification (the hydrogen lean syngas contained CO2 and CH4) FT over the 3DOM Fe based catalyst, and CO2 and CH4 selectivity were 12–26% and 2.67–5.5% respectively. Keywords Three-dimensionally ordered macro-porous (3DOM) Iron catalyst Fischer–Tropsch synthesis Syngas 1 Introduction With the challenges of diminishing the traditional petroleum reserves and increasing the environmental concerns, the thermo-chemical conversion of biomass to liquid fuels (BTL) has been regarded as one of the promising routes of producing tomorrow's liquid transportation fuels [1]. Fischer Tropsch (FT) synthesis, as one of the key technologies in the BTL process, has been attracted to more attention in recent years [2]. The syngas is mainly converted into a range of hydrocarbons of various molecular weights according to the following reactions [3]: (1) n C O + ( 2 n + 1 ) H 2 → C n H 2 n + 2 + n H 2 O (2) n C O + 2 n H 2 → C n H 2 n + n H 2 O (3) n C O + 2 n H 2 → C n H 2 n + 2 O + ( n − 1 ) H 2 O Unfortunately, the biomass-derived syngas is not optimal for the commercial catalysts (Fe and Co based catalysts) because of the low H2/CO ratio (0.45–1.03) [4]. Biomass steam-oxygen gasification usually produces the hydrogen lean biosyngas which contains 25–30% H2 and 43–47% CO [5], and the hydrogen lean biosyngas from the biomass ambient air gasification usually contains 18–20% H2, 20–24% CO, 9–12% CO2, 1–4% CH4 and nitrogen as the balance [6]. The relative high level of CO2 lowered the partial pressures of CO+H2 and the rate of hydrocarbon formation. Moreover, the active iron carbide phase of catalyst would be oxidized by CO2 [7]. Hence, enormous efforts have been made to improve the gas utilization efficiency of these H2-lean biosyngasses. The activity and selectivity of catalysts could be promoted by adding promoters such as alkali metals, Cu, and the noble metals (Ru, Rh, Pt, etc.) or metal oxides (ZrO2, La2O3, MnO) [8–12]. The improvement of the structure, textural and morphology of catalysts supports was an alternative method of enhancing the selectivity and activity of catalysts [13,14]. Hou et al. reported that three dimensionally ordered (3DOM) catalysts could significantly improve the catalytic performance for CO oxidation because 3DOM catalysts were beneficial for the reactant species diffusion. At the same time, the existence of the meso-porous and macro-porous may simultaneously provide the high surface areas and more active sites [15]. Zhang et al. also found that the cobalt catalyst supported on a meso-porous support with larger pore diameter had achieved better activity and C5+ selectivity [16]. Jung et al. stated that the catalyst supported on a meso–macro pore structure support showed a more stabilized catalytic activity and better heavy hydrocarbon selectivity in the FT reaction compared to other catalysts [17]. However, the syngas from biomass gasification contains 9–12% CO2, and the previous researches did not concern FT synthesis using the model biosyngas with CO2. The present work focuses on developing a novel 3DOM Fe based catalyst using PMMA microspheres as templates (no rare-earth metal addition), and coverts the model syngas (contain CO2 and CH4) from biomass gasification into the liquid hydrocarbons. The effects of the syngas compositions on the surface carbonaceous species formation, phase transformations and catalytic performance over the 3DOM Fe based catalyst will also be discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation In this study, the mono-dispersed PMMA microspheres were synthesized by a modified dual-phase emulsifier-free emulsion polymerization method [18,19]. The batch polymerization reactor for synthesizing Poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) microspheres was shown in SFig. 1. For synthesizing 3DOM Fe based FTS catalyst, 44ml Ethylene Glycol (EG) and 6ml methanol were mixed in a 100ml beaker, then 40.g iron nitrate was added into the EG-methanol mixture. The solution was stirred with a speed of 50 r/min at room temperature for 2.5h, and the precursor solution was formed. The dried PMMA template was then added into the well-mixed precursor solution for 3h. The excess precursor was removed by a vacuum filtration, and an impregnated PMMA template was obtained. After drying, the impregnated PMMA template-precursor sample was finally mixed with quartz sand and calcined in a quartz tube reactor at the ramping rate of 1°C/min from room temperature to 650°C, and maintained at 650°C for 3h. Thus, the 3DOM Fe based FT catalyst was prepared. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The morphology of PMMA was characterized by Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope (JEOL JSM-6500F, JEOL USA, Inc., Waterford, VA) with an operating voltage of 5kV. The morphology of 3DOM iron based catalyst was also characterized by Zeiss SUPRA 40 FEG-SEM system (Thornwood, NY) with an operating voltage of 10kV. Moreover, High Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HRTEM) images were obtained through JEOL 2100 electron microscope (JEOL, Japan). The structure properties (the specific surface area, average pore diameter, and pore volume) of 3DOM Fe based catalysts were determined using Quantachrome Autosorb-1C instrument (Boynton Beach, FL).Temperature Programmed Reduction (TPR) profile of the fresh catalyst was recorded using a Quantachrome ChemBET PULSAR apparatus (Boynton Beach, FL) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The phase composition and crystalline structure of the catalysts were determined using an Ultima III X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku Americas, The Woodlands, TX). X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were taken by a PHI 1600 XPS surface Analysis System (Physical Electronics, Eden Prairie, MN). DRIFTS spectra were obtained using a Bruker FTIR Tensor 27 with a MCT detector in conjunction with Praying Mantis™ Diffuse Reflection Accessory (Billerica, MA). 2.3 Reactor system and operation procedure The catalytic performance tests were carried out in a micro tubular fixed bed reactor system. The detailed configuration and description of the reactor system can be found in our previous paper [20]. Before each run, 0.125g 3DOM Fe based FT catalyst was uniformly mixed with the glass beads (the diameter was about 2mm) to form 10 vol.% catalyst mixture, then 3DOM Fe based FTS catalyst mixture was loaded into the reactor tube and reduced by the syngas (50% H2 and 50% CO) at 350°C, 0.35MPa, and 1000h−1 of Gas Hourly Space Velocity (GHSV) for 24h. After the reduction, the feed gas was switched to the predetermined reactant gas, and the operation parameters were gradually increased to the predetermined parameters (List in Table 3 ) for FT reaction. GHSV was fixed at 3600h−1 in all the tests, while other parameters such as the temperature (270–310°C) and pressure (2.14–3.79MPa) were varied. Three types of syngas were used in the tests, as summarized in Table 1 (SG21 mean the syngas with 2.0H2/CO ratio; SG11 mean the syngas with 1.0H2/CO ratio; SB mean the simulated biosyngas from biomass gasification, which contains 12% CO2 and 2% CH4). The gas at the outlet of the reactor was analyzed using an online Agilent 7890 Gas Chromatography (Santa Clara, CA) with helium and nitrogen as carrier gases. A HP Plot capillary column was used to analyze the gaseous hydrocarbons (C1-C4 ranged alkanes and alkenes) with a Flame Ionization Detector (FID) and a molecular sieve-packed column was used to analyze CO, CO2, CH4, and N2 with a Thermal Conductivity Detector (TCD). The liquid hydrocarbons collected from the condenser were analyzed via a Detailed Hydrocarbon Analyzer (NARL 6560 MODEL 4060,Waltham, MA), which was composed of a Perkin Elmer Clarus 680 GC with a FID detector. Nitrogen in the syngas was assumed as inert during the reaction. CO and H2 conversion rates were defined as the mole percentage of carbon monoxide and hydrogen reacted during FT reaction, as shown in Eqs. (4) and (5), respectively. Product selectivity was defined as the mole percentage of CO converted into the specific product during FT reaction, as shown in Esq. (6)–(8): (4) C O c o n v e r s i o n r a t e ( m o l % ) = C O i n − C O o u t C O i n × 100 (5) H 2 c o n v e r s i o n r a t e ( m o l % ) = H 2 i n − H 2 o u t H 2 i n × 100 (6) C O 2 s e l e c t i v i t y ( m o l % ) = n u m b e r o f C O c o n v e r t e d t o C O 2 t o t a l n u m b e r o f C O c o n v e r t e d × 100 (7) C 1 − 4 s e l e c t i v i t y ( m o l % ) = n u m b e r o f C O c o n v e r t e d t o C 1 − C 4 t o t a l n u m b e r o f C O c o n v e r t e d × 100 (8) C 5 + s e l e c t i v i t y ( m o l % ) = 100 - C O 2 s e l e c t i v i t y - C 1 − 4 s e l e c t i v i t y The detailed FTS performance data, regarding the catalyst activity, selectivity and liquid hydrocarbon quality, are summarized in Table 3. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphology and structure of 3DOM Fe catalyst Fig. 1 (a) showed SEM images of the assembled colloidal crystal PMMA template synthesized from the emulsifier-free emulsion polymerization reaction and centrifugal assembly. It was observed from the images that the particle size distribution of PMMA microspheres was very narrow with an average diameter of 335nm. The shape of the microsphere was highly uniform and spherical was formed. The Face-Centered Cubic (FCC) crystal structure was observed in the template, which was the most thermodynamically stable compared with other structures, such as Body-Centered Cubic (BCC) and Hexagonal Close-Packed (HCP) [21]. At the same time, the template was highly uniform and ordered in the three- dimensional scale. An obvious color change could be observed from the prepared template, which indicated that the Bragg diffraction occurred in the visible wave length light and further demonstrated the three-dimensional ordered structure of the obtained template [21]. SEM images of the 3DOM iron based catalyst were shown in Fig. 1(b). It could be observed that the catalyst had the highly ordered three-dimensional structure derived from the PMMA template. The hierarchical structure contained the spherical macro-pores with an average diameter of 210nm. The macro-pores were inter-connected with each other through the small windows on the wall with an average thickness of 15nm. The shrinkage of macro-pores from the initial sizes of the PMMA template was due to the melting of the polymer microspheres during the template removing process and condensation of the intermediate compounds. 3.2 BET characterization The detailed structure properties including BET surface area, pore volume and average pore diameter, were summarized in Table 2. The surface area of the fresh 3DOM Fe catalyst was 33.07m2/g, while the surface area of the reduced catalyst was increased sharply to 115.8m2/g. After FT reaction, the surface areas were decreased to 92.45m2/g (SG21), 15.1m2/g (SG11), and 17.44m2/g (SB), respectively. The pore volume of the fresh catalyst was 0.20cm3/g, while the pore volume increased to 0.67cm3/g for the reduced catalyst. The pore volume of the spent catalysts decreased to 0.44cm3/g(SG21), 0.04cm3/g(SG11), and 0.07cm3/g(SB), respectively. This tendency was agreed with the observation from the changes of hysteresis loop in SFig. 2 (Supplementary data). The increase of surface area and pore volume on the reduced catalyst was majorly attributed to the reduction of iron oxide and generation of meso-pores on the macro-porous walls. During FT reaction, the carbonaceous species would gradually deposit on the catalyst surface and block the pores, so that the surface area and pore volume were decreased [22]. Compared with the fresh catalyst, the BET surface area and pore volume of the spent catalysts were significantly decreased, and the BET surface used in SG21, SG11 and SB were 92, 15 and 17m2/g, respectively. This was consistent with the average pore diameter, the average pore diameter of reduced catalyst was 25nm, while he catalyst spent in hydrogen rich syngas (SG21) had 18.95nm pore diameter, the catalysts spent in hydrogen lean syngas had much smaller pore diameters of 14.44nm (SG11) and 10.68nm (SB), respectively. 3.3 HRTEM characterization HRTEM images of the catalysts were shown in Fig. 2 . The diffraction spacing at 2.20Å was observed in Fig. 2(a), corresponding to the lattice plane (113) of hematite [23], which was consistent with the result of TPR profile (S Fig. 3). Fig. 2(b) showed Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) of the fresh catalyst, which suggested that α-Fe2O3 was aligned along the [12-1] zone axis. The HRTEM image of the reduced catalyst was shown in Fig. 2(c). The diffraction spacing at 2.08Å was attributed to FexC formation. It was also observed that the reduced catalyst was well carburized and majorly composed of iron carbide species in the bulk of catalyst. A small grain area with a diffraction spacing at 2.53Å was observed in the near surface of the reduced catalyst, which was attributed to the lattice plane (311) of magnetite. The diffraction spacing at 3.35Å was attributed to the lattice plane (003) of graphite, which means that the catalyst surface was covered by carbonaceous species. 3.4 XRD characterization Fig. 3 (a) demonstrated that there was only α-Fe2O3 in the fresh catalyst, which was consistent with the results of TPR and HRTEM. After the reduction, the diffraction peaks corresponding to the crystal planes (111), (200), (220) and (311) at the two theta of 43.278, 50.403, 74.052 and 89.839, respectively, confirmed the formation of Austenite-phase iron carbide (CFe15.1) in the reduced catalyst, it was also consistent with JCPDS PDF#52-0512 [24–26]. Moreover, the diffraction peaks of Hägg carbide (Fe5C2), Eckstrom-Adcock iron carbide (Fe7C3) and magnetite (Fe3O4) were also found in Fig. 3(b). At the same time, there was also graphite in the reduced catalyst. The results indicated that the reduction of 3DOM Fe based catalyst by the syngas could transform hematite in the fresh catalyst into iron carbide mixtures (Fe5C2, Fe7C3, and CFe15.1) and magnetite (Fe3O4). After FT reaction in the hydrogen rich syngas (SG21), the peak intensities of iron carbide species decreased, while the relative peak intensities of magnetite increased. Meanwhile, the concentration of graphite was drastically decreased, as shown in Fig. 3(c). However, the peaks of the iron carbide species almost disappeared, only a small amount of Fe5C2 existed when the 3DOM Fe based catalyst was used in the hydrogen lean syngas (SG11), as shown in Fig. 3(d). This might be the result of the outward diffusion of carbidic carbon and the oxidation of iron carbides with water to form magnetite [27]. Fig. 3(e) presented that Fe5C2 concentration in the catalyst used in SB was higher than that of SG11. The dissociative adsorption of methane on the iron catalyst surface and carburization of the iron phase through methane prevented the decarburization of iron carbide phase. 3.5 XPS characterization XPS was also used to investigate the property and composition of surface layers on the 3DOM Fe based catalyst. Fig. 4 presented the high resolution XPS spectra in Fe 2p region of the catalysts. As shown in Fig. 4(a), there was the peak at 710.6eV and its shoulder peak at 718.7eV, which was attributed to Fe2O3. After the reduction, Fe 2P peak at 710.6eV and its shoulder peak at 718.7eV disappeared, as Fig. 4(b). However, two weak peaks at 715.4eV and 706.9eV were observed, which attributed to the formation of Fe3O4 and Fe in the surface of the reduced catalyst [28]. The characteristic peaks of the catalyst after FT reaction were similar with those of the reduced catalyst. Fig. 5 demonstrated the high resolution XPS spectra in C 1s region of the catalysts, as shown in Fig. 5(a), a peak at 284.6eV appeared in C 1s region, which was the residue during the PMMA template removal process [29]. The reduction by the syngas resulted in the formation of iron carbide, as indicated by the peak at 283.5eV (Fig. 5(b)) [30]. In the spectra of the spent catalysts, C 1s peaks shifted to much lower binding energies at 281.0eV, which attributed to the shielding effect of the carbonaceous deposits on the catalysts surface during the FT reaction [31]. 3.6 DRIFTS characterization The in situ DRIFT spectra of the adsorbed species on the catalysts were compared in Fig. 6 . Fig. 6(a) presented that there were the bands at 1635, 1538, 1403, 1328, 1186, and 1122cm−1in the fresh catalyst, which was assigned to carbonates originated from PMMA template [28]. The band at 2970 and 2926cm−1appeared on the reduced catalyst (Fig. 6(b)) corresponded to asymmetric CH stretching vibrations of CH2- species, which suggested that FT active sites had appeared on the surface layer, and promoted the formation of hydrocarbon species [32]. For the spent catalysts, the catalyst spent in hydrogen rich syngas SG21 (Fig. 6c) had the similar spectra with the reduced catalyst on Fig. 6(b), except that a weak band at 1581cm−1 corresponded to formate species on the catalyst [33]. More bands (1451 and 1328cm−1) were observed in the spectra of the spent catalysts in the hydrogen lean syngas of SG11 and SB, as shown in Fig. 6(d) and Fig. 6(e), which indicated more complex carbonaceous species were formed on the surfaces of catalysts reacted in the hydrogen lean syngas environment. Mao et al. also stated that the band around 1451cm−1 was surface methoxy species, which might arise from formate reduction in the presence of hydrogen [34]. The band at 1328cm−1 was also assigned to formate species [33]. However, the intensities of the bands were lower when CO2 and CH4 were introduced into the syngas, which indicated the incorporation of CO2 and CH4 into the syngas would produce less concentration of the carbonaceous species. 3.7 FT performance of the 3DOM Fe catalyst 3.7.1 The activity In SG21 FT reaction, the CO conversion rate was increased from 94.2% to 99.77% when the reaction temperature was raised from 270 to 290°C. When in the SG11 FT reaction the temperature was raised from 270 to 290°C, the CO conversion rate increased from 43.93% to 98.02%. The above results indicated that the activity of the catalysts decreased when H2/CO was decreased. The decreasing H2/CO ratio improved the CO partial pressure and associated adsorbed CO concentration, which resulted in a lower adsorption and dissociation of H2 and decreases the hydrogenation reaction rate. Therefore, the scarcity of surface H caused the low activity of FT catalyst [35]. In the SB (contain CO2 and CH4), CO concentration or partial pressure was lower than that in SG11. Hence, the reaction temperature was increased to 295–310°C. The CO conversion rate was 59.38% at 295°C, which was slightly lower than that in SG11 at 270°C. When the reaction temperature was increased to 310°C, the CO conversion rate was similar with that of SG11 at 290°C. Moreover, the iron carbides were regarded as the active phase during FT reaction, and the content of iron carbides in the catalyst spent in SG11 was the lowest (Fig. 3). Hence, the activity of SG11 FT was the lowest. In addition, the effect of pressure was also tested for SB. It was shown that both H2 and CO conversions were increased with increasing pressure, the CO conversion rates were 68.23% and 89.35% under 2.96 and 3.79MPa pressure respectively (See Table 3). At a similar CO conversion level, the CO2 selectivity indicates the Water-Gas Shift (WGS) activity [36]. The CO2selectivity during SG21, SG11 and SB FT synthesis over 3DOM Fe catalyst was 26%, 18–19% and 12–14% (Table 3), which were lower than that of other catalysts (Table 4 ). 3.7.2 Product selectivity The FT product selectivity was calculated based on the carbon conversion, as Eqs. (3)–(5). In the hydrogen rich syngas SG21, the selectivity of carbon dioxide varied from 12.08% to 14.77%. The selectivity of light hydrocarbons (C1-C4) varied from 3.00% to 4.17%, and the selectivity of heavy hydrocarbons (C5+) varied from 81.06% to 84.92%. In the hydrogen lean syngas SG11, the catalyst had a higher selectivity of carbon dioxide, which varied from 18.56% to 19.28%. The selectivity of light hydrocarbons varied from 4.59% to 5.55%, and the selectivity of heavy hydrocarbons varied from 75.17% to 76.85% in the temperature range of 270–290°C. In the hydrogen lean syngas contained CO2 and CH4 added (SB), with the change of temperature, the selectivity of carbon dioxide varied from 26.00% to 26.31%, the selectivity of light hydrocarbons varied from 2.8% to 3.25%, and the selectivity of heavy hydrocarbons varied from 71.2% to 70.66% though the partial pressure of CO and H2 was the lowest. The methane and carbon dioxide selectivity of 3DOM Fe catalyst was lower compared to the published catalysts. Todic et al. reported that the increasing temperature promoted the amount of light products while that of heavy products decreased, which was linked to a decrease in chain growth probability [37]. With the change of pressure, the selectivity of carbon dioxide varied from 26.20% to 26.96%, the selectivity of light hydrocarbons varied from 3.25% to 2.67%, and the selectivity of heavy hydrocarbons varied from 70.44% to 71.13%. Apparently, with the decreasing of H2/CO ratio, the selectivity of catalyst was gradually shifted to CO2 and light hydrocarbons. It might be attributed to more active water gas shift reaction and methanation capability within the hydrogen lean syngas environment. The introduction of CO2 and CH4 into the hydrogen lean syngas facilitated the generation of CO2 while it suppressed the formation of light hydrocarbons. The liquid hydrocarbon distribution was also summarized in Table 3. It was shown that the liquid hydrocarbons were majorly composed of straight-chain paraffins (Paraffins), branched-chain paraffins (I-Paraffins), Olefins, Naphthenes, and less percentage of Aromatics. In SG21, it was shown that the distribution of Paraffins, Olefins, and Aromatics increased from 26.24% to 31.27%, 24.93% to 30.74%, 10.40% to 12.48% respectively when the reaction temperature was increased from 270 to 290°C. While the distribution of I-Paraffins, and Naphthenes decreased from 12.47% to 10.67%, 25.95% to 14.64% with the increase of the reaction temperature. In SG11, the liquid hydrocarbon distribution displayed a different tendency. When the reaction temperature varied from 270 to 290°C, the distribution of Paraffins, I-Paraffins and Olefins increased from 20.02% to 24.82%, 16.91% to 19.07%, 28.00% to 35.95%. However, the distribution of Naphthenes and Aromatics dropped from 25.45% to 14%, 9.62% to 6.17%. Obviously, the hydrogen lean syngas SG11 produced more I-Paraffins and Olefins, less Paraffins and Aromatics than those of the hydrogen rich syngas SG21, while the distribution of aromatics was at a similar level for the two syngasses. Compared with SG11, the liquid hydrocarbons from the hydrogen lean syngas contained CO2 and CH4 displayed the distinctly different hydrocarbon distribution. It was shown that the distribution of Paraffins in SB varied from 5.52% to 6.75%, which was much less than the Paraffins distribution in SG11. The distribution of I-Paraffins was slightly higher than that of SG11, which varied from 20.36% to 20.88%. The distribution of Olefins varied from 40.95% to 45.15%, which was much higher than the Olefins distribution in SG11. The distribution of both Naphthenes and Aromatics were similar with those in SG11. 3.7.3 Liquid hydrocarbon quality Comparing the O/P (olefins/(paraffins+I-paraffins)) ratios of liquid hydrocarbons, it was found that the liquid hydrocarbons produced from SG21 had the least O/P ratio, and O/P varied from 0.64 to 0.77. The liquid hydrocarbons from SG11 had an O/P range of 0.76–0.91, and the O/P of liquid hydrocarbon from SB had a range of 1.51–1.71. It was obvious that more hydrogen in the feed syngas would lead to more paraffin products, which was consistent with the study of Ordomsky and Khodakov [38], who reported that the increasing H2 partial pressure and decreasing CO partial pressure would result in the termination of the surface species to paraffins. Additionally, Table 3 also showed that the appearance of carbon dioxide and methane in the feed gas would result in the double yield of olefins in the final liquid products though the partial pressure of CO and H2 was decreased. The carbon and hydrogen mass percent in the liquid hydrocarbons had the similar values in spite of the different gas compositions used in the tests. To further understand liquid hydrocarbon quality, the octane number and bromine number were determined at Mississippi state chemical laboratory according to ASTM D 2699 and ASTM D 2710. The average octane number of the liquid hydrocarbons from the three different syngasses were 55.00, 50.00, and 58.27, respectively. The average bromine number of the liquid hydrocarbons were 34.77, 28.60, and 35.65, respectively. Obviously, the hydrogen rich syngas produced higher octane number and bromine number hydrocarbons than those of the hydrogen lean syngas. However, the existence of other carbon sources in the hydrogen lean syngas greatly improved the octane number of the final liquid products. The average relative density of the liquid hydrocarbons from the syngas was 0.71, 0.71, and 0.74, respectively. The average molecular weight of the liquid hydrocarbons was 109.46, 120.00, and 126.47, respectively. The average Reid vapor pressure of the liquid hydrocarbons was 3.28, 2.30, and 1.57, respectively. Apparently, the decreasing hydrogen concentration in the feed syngas would shift the liquid products into higher molecular weight hydrocarbons, the addition of CO2 and CH4 would further facilitate the shift. Moreover, the decreases of CO and H2 partial pressure in SB were also attributed to the above phenomena. A comparison of the catalytic performances of the 3DOM Fe based catalysts with other types of Fe catalysts in FT reaction was summarized in Table 4 [14,37,39–44]. The 3DOM Fe based catalysts had a higher active CO conversion rate and selectivity of C5+ liquid hydrocarbons than those precipitated, or porous materials supported Fe based catalysts. Because 1-olefins were the intermediates of FTS, and small pores of catalyst could limit the mass transfer efficiency of 1-olefins, enhancing the methane selectivity. While the 3DOM catalysts simultaneously had the meso-porous and macro-porous, which could overcome the mass transfer limitation, and the reactants/products diffused in and out of the pores of catalyst more easily, resulting in higher chain growth probability and higher C5+ selectivity [16]. The stability of 3DOM catalyst was tested at 310°C, 279Mpa, GHSV of 3600h−1 with SB syngas. Fig. 7 showed CO and H2 conversions decreased in the first 3h and then increased steadily during the first 10 h, and then stabilized at 89.35% and 88.77%, respectively. After achieving the steady state, the total hydrocarbons selectivity was 88.3%, 65% of which was C5+ hydrocarbons. In the reduction process, the temperature was 350°C and the pressure was 0.35Mpa. After the shift to Fishcher-Tropsch synthesis process, the temperature was decreased from 350to 310°C, which caused the CO conversion rate to decrease(in the first 3h). Then, the CO conversion rate was increased with the pressure under 310°C, and reached the equilibrium at 10h. 4 Conclusions In this paper, the 3DOM Fe based catalysts were prepared. The freshly synthesized 3DOM Fe based catalyst was majorly composed of Fe2O3 with the highly organized hierarchical structure, and the average diameter of the macro-pores was 210nm. The macro-pores were inter-connected with each other through the small windows on the wall with an average thickness of 15nm. After the reduction, the hematite in the fresh 3DOM Fe catalyst was converted to a large amount of iron carbides (χ-Fe5C2, Fe7C3, and CFe15.1) and a small amount of magnetite. At the same time, the reduced catalyst was covered with graphite and amorphous carbon. When reacting in the hydrogen rich syngas, parts of iron carbides were gradually transformed into magnetite due to the oxidation of iron carbides with water, and graphite was gradually removed from the catalyst surface. With decreasing hydrogen content in the syngas, iron carbides almost disappeared and only a small amount of χ-Fe5C2 could be found in the catalyst. After introduction of CO2 and CH4 into the hydrogen lean syngas, iron carbide phase (majorly χ-Fe5C2) was well-preserved in the catalyst. In both types of the hydrogen lean syngas, carbonaceous species on the catalyst surface were transformed into chaoite (also known as carbyne species). 3DOM Fe based catalyst demonstrated an excellent activity in converting three types of syngas with different H2/CO ratios into the liquid hydrocarbons, and its activity was not significantly affected by introducing CO2 and CH4 into the syngas except for the increase of the optimum reaction temperature (about 25°C). At the same time, CO2 and CH4 in the feeding syngas apparently resulted in the double yield of olefins. Lower H2/CO ratios syngas would shift the liquid hydrocarbon distribution to higher molecular weight hydrocarbons, and the addition of CO2 and CH4 in the syngas further facilitated the shift. The methane and carbon dioxide selectivity of 3DOM Fe catalyst was lower compared to the published catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Three-Dimensionally Ordered Macro-porous (3DOM) Fe based catalysts were synthesized via a facile “glyoxylate route” poly (methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) colloidal crystal template (CCT) method. Fischer Tropsch Synthesis (FT) using different biosyngasses over the 3DOM Fe based catalyst for producing the liquid hydrocarbon was studied. The morphology, structure and microstructures of 3DOM Fe based catalysts were characterized by SEM, BET, TPR, HRTEM, XRD, XPS and DRIFTS. The experimental results demonstrated that the hydrogen lean syngas decreased the partial pressure of H2/CO, which caused the decrease of the CO conversion rate during FT reaction. Moreover, the addition of CO2 and CH4 in the hydrogen lean syngas could well preserve the iron carbide phase in the catalyst, and the CO conversion rate was improved. Lower H2/CO ratio syngas would shift the liquid hydrocarbon distribution to higher molecular weight hydrocarbons, and the addition of CO2 and CH4 into the syngas further facilitated the shift. Meanwhile, it was also found that the CO conversion rate and C5+ selectivity were 68.23% and 70.44% respectively during the simulated biosyngas from biomass gasification (the hydrogen lean syngas contained CO2 and CH4) FT over the 3DOM Fe based catalyst, and CO2 and CH4 selectivity were 12–26% and 2.67–5.5% respectively.
coredata.dc:title: The effect of syngas composition on the Fischer Tropsch synthesis over three-dimensionally ordered macro-porous iron based catalyst
